explosives.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive properties

flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

flammable_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

self_reactive_substances.rationale: The kick-off temperature is considered to exceed 75degC. According to HSDB (2006), anhydrous zinc sulfate forms when its hydrates are heated above 238degC, and at about 680degC, SO3 separates from the compound, forming 3ZnO.2SO3.

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data, though being organic compounds containing oxygen bound to the elements other than carbon and hydrogen.

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Test methods applicable to solid substances are not available

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the LD50 value of 1,260mg/kg calculated from the testing data of rat LD50 (oral route) of 1,710mg/kg (CERI Hazard Data 98-1 (1999), EHC 221 (2001)), 2,940mg/kg (CERI Hazard Data 98-1 (1999), EU-RAR No.46 (2004)), 920mg/kg and 2,280mg/kg (EU-RAR No.46 (2004)). These data might probably refer to hydrates, and not anhydrides. Note: As for the classification of 7-hydrate, refer to "ID1108, CAS# 7446-70-0."

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "solid" according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

acute_toxicity_inhalation_vapor.rationale: No data available. Note: As for the classification of 7-hydrate, refer to "ID1108, CAS# 7446-70-0."

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.rationale: No data available Note: As for the classification of 7-hydrate, refer to "ID1108, CAS# 7446-70-0."

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: No data available. Note: As for the classification of 7-hydrate, refer to "ID1108, CAS# 7446-70-0."

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Based on the description in the report on rabbit eye irritation tests (exposure duration unknown) (EU-RAR No.46 (2004)): "Yellow/white spots were observed in the tissue of the lower eyelid, nictitating membrane and/or sclera in all animals from day 7 until termination. These spots were described as signs of necrosis," "severe ocular irritation." Also based on the description of the human health effects (CERI Hazard Data 2001-29 (2002)): "The substance produced grayish pigmentation of the cornea, leaving the crystalline lens spotted after recovery." The substance is thus considered to be a very strong irritant. These data might probably refer to hydrates. Note: As for the classification of 7-hydrate, refer to "ID1108, CAS# 7446-70-0."

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Based on the description in the report on guinea pig skin sensitization tests (EU-RAR No.46 (2004)): "Zinc sulphate is not considered a skin sensitization." Also based on the description in the report on mouse skin sensitization tests (IUCLID (2000)): "Not sensitizing."

carcinogenicity.rationale: Based on negative data on multi-generation mutagenicity tests (dominant lethal tests), the absence of data on germ cell mutagenicity tests in vivo and germ cell genotoxicity tests in vivo, and positive data on somatic cell mutagenicity tests in vivo (micronucleus tests and chromosome aberration tests), described in ATSDR (2005), EU-RAR No.46 (2004), EHC 221 (2001) and CERI Hazard Data 2001-29 (2002).

toxic_to_reproduction.rationale: Classification not possible based on expert judgment in the absence of existing classification (though some toxicity data are available).

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement: Suspected of damaging fertility or the unborn child
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: Based on the evidence of adverse effects on reproduction/development (decreased male/female fertility and implantation), described in EU-RAR No.46 (2004), ATSDR (2005) and EHC 221 (2001) (though no data are available regarding parental toxicity).

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: Causes damage to organs (kidney, liver, respiratory system)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: Based on the human evidence: "... the kidneys were damaged and proteinuria, glucosuria and acetonuria were detected," "... vomiting, diarrhea, jaundice, oliguresis were noted; autopsy findings consisted of renal tubular necrosis, hyaline membrane in the lung and changes in the liver" (CERI Hazard Data 2001-29 (2002)).

aspiration_hazard.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
aspiration_hazard.hazard_statement: Cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (pancreas, adrenal gland, cardiovascular system)
aspiration_hazard.rationale: Based on the human evidence including "islet cell hypertrophy and betacell vacuolization were observed," "hypertrophy of suprarenal cortical cells, and increased lipid" (ATSDR (1980)), "obstructive vascular disease" (ATSDR (1980)).

acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: It was classified into Category 1 from 96 hours LC50=0.061mg/L(Zinc Sulfate Equivalent=0.151mg/L) of the fish (Cutthroat Trout) (EHC221, 2001).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: Very toxic to aquatic life with long lasting effects
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since although acute toxicity was Category 1 and bio-accumulation was low (BCF=242 (existing chemical safety inspections data)), it was a metallic compound, and the underwater action was unknown, it was classified into Category 1.
